responses:
The Vision of Bisu is A Premier Science and Technology University for the formation of a world class and virtuous human resource for sustainable development in Bohol and the Country. And Mission is committed to provide quality and innovative education in strategic sectors for the development of Bohol and the country. Here are the goals of Bisu:
 1. Develop and offer quality and innovative curricular programs and instructional systems to meet the human resource requirements of the strategic sectors.
 2. Plan and implement a focused R & D and Extension agenda.
 3. Enhance institution capability in resource generation.
 4. Promote effective governance and deliver efficient administrative and support services.
 5. Develop and promote a culture of quality service and excellence.

The Mission of BISU is committed to provide quality and innovative education in strategic sectors for the development of Bohol and the country. A premier Science and Technology university for the formation of a world class and virtuous human resource for sustainable development in Bohol and the Country is the vision. The goals of bisu are to develop and offer quality and innovative curricular programs and instructional systems to meet the human resource requirements of the strategic sectors. Plan and implement a focused R & D and Extension agenda. Enhance institution capability in resource generation. Promote effective governance and deliver efficient administrative and support services. Develop and promote a culture of quality service and excellence.

A Premier Science and Technology University for the formation of a world class and virtuous human resource for sustainable development in Bohol and the Country is the vision.  5. Develop and promote a culture of quality service and excellence are the goals of Bisu.

responses:
Here are the following Entrance Requirements of Bisu:
 1. All applicants are required to pay testing fee before taking the examination.
 2.Applicants to the Secondary Curriculum:
 *Form 138 (Report Card) with no grade below 80 in the final rating in all subjects,
 *Official receipt of testing fee,
 *Certificate of Good Moral Character,
 *2pcs colored recent photo (2” x 2” not cut-out).
 3. Applicants to the Degree/Non-Degree Courses:
 *Form 138 (Report Card)/TOR (informative copy),
 *Official Receipt of testing fee,
 *Certificate of Good Moral Character,
 *2 pcs. Colored recent photo (2” x 2” not cut-out).
 4. Applicants for Teacher Education must have at least 85 or 2.0 general average with no grades below 80 or 2.5 in all subjects, excluding Religion. No rounding off Shiftee /second courser must have an average of 85 or 2.0 with no grade below 80 or 2.5 in all subjects, excluding NSTP.
 5. Applicants for BHRST must have a height of at least 5’2” for female and 5’4” for male. BS Tourism applicants must be at least 5’ for female and 5’2” for male.
 6. Students-graduate of a non-degree course who will proceed to Baccalaureate degree must have at least 80 or 2.5 general average in the last course attended, and must pass the entrance examination in the course he/she intends to enroll. One should submit his/her records for evaluation to the Dean before he/she can be admitted.
 7. A transferee and shiftee in other board courses must have at least 80 or 2.5 general average in the last course attended.
 8. Applicants must submit their records to the department deans for evaluation.
 9. Applicants for the College of Advanced Studies:
 Master of Education in Educational Management - Applicants must be a graduate of Teacher Education course or any related course with 18 units professional subjects in Education.
 Master of Arts in Teaching Vocational Education -Applicants must be a graduate of BSED-THE, BSIE, BTE, and BSIT or any related course with 18 units professional subjects in Education.
 Master in Agriculture and Development - Applicants must be a graduate In Agriculture or any related course.
 Master of Science in Industrial Technology - Applicants must be a graduate of BSIT or any course allied to technology.
 In Master of Science in Mathematics - applicants must be A graduate of BSED major in Mathematics or any course allied to Mathematics.
 Master of Public Administration - Applicants must be a graduate of any 4-year degree course, most preferably one working in a government agency.
 10. Post Advanced Studies:
 Doctor of Philosophy in Technology Management - Applicants must be a graduate of Master of Arts in Teaching Vocational Education, Master in Technician Education, Master of Science in Industrial Technology and any Master degree course allied to Technology.
 Doctor of Education major in Educational Management - Applicants must be a graduate of Master’s Degree course in Education.

responses:
Yes, student can receive a refund if they transfer to another school or who are granted of a certificate of transfer credentials of the amount paid for their tuition and other fees, in accordance with the following:
 Before classes start - 80%
 Within the first week of classes - 70%
 Within the second week of classes - 50%
 Within the third week of classes - 20%
 After the third week of classes - no refund

Students who are granted certificate of transfer credentials or have withdrawn shall be entitled to a refund of the amount paid for their tuition and other fees, in accordance with the following:
 Before classes start - 80%
 Within the first week of classes - 70%
 Within the second week of classes - 50%
 Within the third week of classes - 20%
 After the third week of classes – no refund.

Students who receive a certificate of transfer credentials or choose to withdraw are eligible for a refund based on the following schedule:
 Before classes start - 80%
 Within the first week of classes - 70%
 Within the second week of classes - 50%
 Within the third week of classes - 20%
 After the third week of classes – no refund.

responses:
REGISTRATION REGULATIONS
 1. Old student who have committed major offenses shall be enrolled only upon recommendation by the Dean of College and Approval of the Campus Director or University President.
 2. All students should enroll during the scheduled dated of their college/department. Failure to enroll during the period set means payment of a penalty prescribed by the BOR.
 3. All first year college students should enroll in NSTP.
 4. A student can enroll upon payment of at least 10% of the total assessment of his school fees for the semester.
 5. Students who are granted certificate of transfer credentials or have withdrawn shall be entitled to a refund of the amount paid for their tuition and other fees, in accordance with the following:
 Before classes start - 80%
 Within the first week of classes - 70%
 Within the second week of classes - 50%
 Within the third week of classes - 20%
 After the third week of classes - no refund
 6. Old students should present their ID cards upon enrolment for validation by the Student Affairs Office (SAO).

THESE ARE THE REGISTRATION REGULATIONS OF BISU:
 1. Old student who have committed major offenses shall be enrolled only upon recommendation by the Dean of College and Approval of the Campus Director or University President.
 2. All students should enroll during the scheduled dated of their college/department. Failure to enroll during the period set means payment of a penalty prescribed by the BOR.
 3. All first year college students should enroll in NSTP.
 4. A student can enroll upon payment of at least 10% of the total assessment of his school fees for the semester.
 5. Students who are granted certificate of transfer credentials or have withdrawn shall be entitled to a refund of the amount paid for their tuition and other fees, in accordance with the following:
 Before classes start - 80%
 Within the first week of classes - 70%
 Within the second week of classes - 50%
 Within the third week of classes - 20%
 After the third week of classes - no refund
 6. Old students should present their ID cards upon enrolment for validation by the Student Affairs Office (SAO).

responses:
OVERLOAD/UNDERLOAD

 1. College students found to be academically deficient shall be deloaded by one or two subjects to allow them to cope with the work load.
 2. A college graduating student may be allowed to take a maximum of six (6) extra units during the last semester duly approved by the Campus Director upon recommendation of the Dean of college.
 3. A secondary graduating student will be allowed an extra load of one (1) subject during the last year; however one is allowed an overload of two (2) subjects with the approval of the Campus Director duly recommended by the Head, Laboratory High School.
 4. Qualified applicants must enroll on their scheduled dates. Non-qualified applicants will be advised to go back to the guidance center for further instructions on what appropriate course to take based on one’s aptitude and interest.

 (Note: Graduate of BISU laboratory high school are exempted from taking the entrance examination unless other exams are required by the College.)
 5. Applicants who have taken the entrance test but wish to enroll in another BISU campus will no longer take an entrance examination if they will enroll in the same course, unless required to take another exam by the college.
 6. Applicants for BHRST, BS Tourism, BS OSM who passed the written exam will undergo the Aptitude test. BS Electrical, BS Electronics, Automotive and Drafting applicants will take the Differential Aptitude Test for course specialization. The following are the cut off scores for the OLSAT (Mental Ability Test):

 a. College of Agriculture & Natural Resources - 40%
 b. College of Health & Allied Sciences - 40%
 c. College of Teacher Education - 40 % And Standardized Aptitude Test for Teachers (SATT) - 60%
 d. College of Business Arts and Sciences - 40% And 80%  of the aptitude test
 e. College of Engineering & Architecture - 40% and Mathematics 60%
 f. College of Technology & Allied Sciences -  40 % and 80% of the Aptitude test

 7. Applicants with minor physical imperfections may be admitted as determined by the screening committee, as long as they can carry out the expected tasks of the course. Those with evident physical defects like cleft-palate, crossed eyes, deafness, single handed/footedness etc., are not accepted in BHRST, Tourism & Teacher Education Programs.

responses:
CHANGING / ADDING / DROPPING OF SUBJECTS

 1. Changing/Adding/Dropping of subjects shall be done only for valid reasons which are stated in writing on prescribed form to be approved by the Dean of College and recorded by the Registrar.
 2. Changing/Adding/Dropping of subjects shall be made within 3 weeks after the start of classes and subject to payment for corresponding fees approved by BOR.
 3. Subject dropped/changed/added unofficially or without prior approval by the College Dean shall not be given credit.
 4. A subject not attended after the prescribed period of changing/adding/dropping of subjects shall be marked “Not Attended” in the rating sheet of the instructor.
 5. A student who dropped after midterm shall be given a failing grade, but for a valid reason he/she shall be marked “DROPPED” indicating the date in the record of the instructor.
 6. Prospective drop-outs shall be referred by the class adviser/subject instructor/Dean to the Guidance Counselor.

ACAMEDIC POLICIES REGARDING CHANGING / ADDING / DROPPING OF SUBJECTS

 1. Changing/Adding/Dropping of subjects shall be done only for valid reasons which are stated in writing on prescribed form to be approved by the Dean of College and recorded by the Registrar.
 2. Changing/Adding/Dropping of subjects shall be made within 3 weeks after the start of classes and subject to payment for corresponding fees approved by BOR.
 3. Subject dropped/changed/added unofficially or without prior approval by the College Dean shall not be given credit.
 4. A subject not attended after the prescribed period of changing/adding/dropping of subjects shall be marked “Not Attended” in the rating sheet of the instructor.
 5. A student who dropped after midterm shall be given a failing grade, but for a valid reason he/she shall be marked “DROPPED” indicating the date in the record of the instructor.
 6. Prospective drop-outs shall be referred by the class adviser/subject instructor/Dean to the Guidance Counselor.

 3. Subject dropped/changed/added unofficially or without prior approval by the College Dean shall not be given credit.

responses:
READMISSION AND RETENTION

 1. A secondary student who fails in two or more related subjects during the school year may be admitted the following school year provided that he will pass the failed subject during summer class.
 2. A college student, except from the College of Engineering, Architecture, Information Technology, Industrial Design and Computer Science, who fails in two or more subjects during the semester will be advised by the Dean to shift to another course or transfer to another school.
 3. College students are subjected to the retention policies of their respective departments.
 4. Students who will undergo OJT and Student Teaching should not have any subject deficiency for the semester.

READMISSION AND RETENTION POLICY IN BISU

 1. A secondary student who fails in two or more related subjects during the school year may be admitted the following school year provided that he will pass the failed subject during summer class.
 2. A college student, except from the College of Engineering, Architecture, Information Technology, Industrial Design and Computer Science, who fails in two or more subjects during the semester will be advised by the Dean to shift to another course or transfer to another school.
 3. College students are subjected to the retention policies of their respective departments.
 4. Students who will undergo OJT and Student Teaching should not have any subject deficiency for the semester.

responses:
TRANSFER OF STUDENT\n
 1. Transferee from other secondary institutions is not eligible for enrolment in the BISU Secondary curriculum, unless the school has similar curriculum, a slot is available, and the applicant passes the entrance examination.
 2. A college transferee must comply at least 50 percent of the units  required to finish his course except from BISU campuses.
 3. Subjects taken from other higher education institutions with the same course title description and number units will be credited.
 4. Only transferees with the complete and valid credentials will be enrolled.

TRANSFER OF STUDENT POLICY IN BISU\n
 1. Transferee from other secondary institutions is not eligible for enrolment in the BISU Secondary curriculum, unless the school has similar curriculum, a slot is available, and the applicant passes the entrance examination.
 2. A college transferee must comply at least 50 percent of the units  required to finish his course except from BISU campuses.
 3. Subjects taken from other higher education institutions with the same course title description and number units will be credited.
 4. Only transferees with the complete and valid credentials will be enrolled.

THESE ARE THE POLICIES REGARDING THE TRANSFER OF STUDENT\n
 1. Transferee from other secondary institutions is not eligible for enrolment in the BISU Secondary curriculum, unless the school has similar curriculum, a slot is available, and the applicant passes the entrance examination.

 4. Only transferees with the complete and valid credentials will be enrolled.

responses:
GRADING SYSTEM OF BISU:

 For Degree and Non-Degree courses:
 Rating - Equivalent - Description
 1.0 - 99-100 - Excellent
 1.1 - 97-98 - Excellent
 1.2 - 95-96 - Excellent
 1.3 - 93-94 - Very Good
 1.4 - 91-92 - Very Good
 1.5 - 90 - Very Good
 1.6 - 89 - Good
 1.7 - 88 - Good
 1.8 - 87 - Good
 1.9 - 86 - Good
 2.0 - 85 - Good
 2.1 - 84 - Good
 2.2 - 83 - Good
 2.3 - 82 - Good
 2.4 - 81 - Good
 2.5 - 80 - Good
 2.6 - 79 - Fair
 2.7 - 78 - Fair
 2.8 - 77 - Fair
 2.9 - 76 - Fair
 3.0 - 75 - Fair
 5.0 - Below 75 - Failure
 NG - No Grade
 DR - Dropped
 NA - Not Attended
 2. NG (no grade) is given to a student who fails to take the final examination or fails to complete all academic requirements for the course on or before the start of classes of the succeeding term. Should he miss to comply the deficiencies within a semester, he shall automatically be given a grade of 5.0.
 3. No incomplete grade (INC) will be given in any subject. Removal examination may be given by the subject teacher within the two-week period after final examination. Students shall pay to the cashier a removal fee as approved by BOT. The highest grade that can be given is 3.0.
 4. DROPPED - A subject dropped before/after midterm shall be marked  as Dropped in the rating sheet of the instructor.
 5. Grading System for College of Advanced Studies Students:
  Academic performance of advanced studies students and post advanced studies students shall be reported at the end of each semester or summer term in accordance with the following grading system:
 Rating - Equivalent - Description
 1.0 - 99-100 - Excellent
 1.1 - 97-98 - Very Good
 1.2 - 95-96 - Very Good
 1.3 - 93-94 - Very Good
 1.4 - 91-92 - Very Good
 1.5 - 89-90 - Good
 1.6 - 87-88 - Good
 1.7 - 85-86 - Good
 1.8 - 83-84 - Good
 1.9 - 80-82 - Good
 2.0 - below 80 - Failure
 NG - No Grade
 NA - Not Attended
 W - Withdraw
 DR - Dropped
 NG entry must be completed within the succeeding semester.
 6.Secondary:
 a. The passing percentage in periodic tests, quizzes, other alternative assessments shall be 60%;
 b. The highest passing grade shall be 100%; the lowest passing grade, 75% and the lowest failing grade is 70%;
 c. Transmutation tables shall be used in the computation of grades;
 d. Final grades shall be determined by averaging the grade marks for the four quarters by subject;
 e. The general average shall be determined by adding the weighted final grades of all subjects.

 2. NG (no grade) is given to a student who fails to take the final examination or fails to complete all academic requirements for the course on or before the start of classes of the succeeding term. Should he miss to comply the deficiencies within a semester, he shall automatically be given a grade of 5.0.
 3. No incomplete grade (INC) will be given in any subject. Removal examination may be given by the subject teacher within the two-week period after final examination. Students shall pay to the cashier a removal fee as approved by BOT. The highest grade that can be given is 3.0.
 4. DROPPED - A subject dropped before/after midterm shall be marked  as Dropped in the rating sheet of the instructor.
 5. Grading System for College of Advanced Studies Students:
 Academic performance of advanced studies students and post advanced studies students shall be reported at the end of each semester or summer term in accordance with the following grading system:
 Rating - Equivalent - Description
 1.0 - 99-100 - Excellent
 1.1 - 97-98 - Very Good
 1.2 - 95-96 - Very Good
 1.3 - 93-94 - Very Good
 1.4 - 91-92 - Very Good
 1.5 - 89-90 - Good
 1.6 - 87-88 - Good
 1.7 - 85-86 - Good
 1.8 - 83-84 - Good
 1.9 - 80-82 - Good
 2.0 - below 80 - Failure
 NG - No Grade
 NA - Not Attended
 W - Withdraw
 DR - Dropped
 NG entry must be completed within the succeeding semester.
6.Secondary:
 a. The passing percentage in periodic tests, quizzes, other alternative assessments shall be 60%;
 b. The highest passing grade shall be 100%; the lowest passing grade, 75% and the lowest failing grade is 70%;
 c. Transmutation tables shall be used in the computation of grades;
 d. Final grades shall be determined by averaging the grade marks for the four quarters by subject;
 e. The general average shall be determined by adding the weighted final grades of all subjects.

responses:
GUIDELINES IN THE SELECTION OF HONOR STUDENTS:

 1. Students who are candidates for graduation with honors must have completed 100% of the total units required for graduation in this institution.
 2. To qualify in the ranking of honors, a student must have at least a general weighted average of 1.75 in all subjects with no grade below 2.0 except NSTP.
 3. The student must have no derogatory records.
 4. The selection of honor students shall be deliberated upon by a committee composed of class advisers of the graduating students, Dean of College, Registrar and Director of Instruction.
 5. No post Advanced Studies students who has a grade lower than 1.5 in any subject can graduate with honors. One shall graduate with honors as follows:
 HONORS- NUMERICAL
 Meritecessimus - 1.0 to 1.19 (general weighted average)
 Benemeritus - 1.20 to 1.29 (general weighted average)
 Meritus - 1.30 to 1.39(General weighted average)
 5b. No College of Advanced Studies student who has a grade lower than .5 in any subject can graduate with honors. Only those with the following numerical ratings will be considered.
 HONORS - NUMERICAL
 Summa Cum Laude - 1.0 to 1.19 (general weighted average)
 Magna Cum Laude - 1.20 to 1.29 (general weighted average)
 Cum Laude - 1.30 to 1.40(General weighted average)
 5c. A student from the Degree program shall graduate with honors as follows:
 HONORS - NUMERICAL
 Summa Cum Laude - 1.0 to 1.25 (general weighted average) with no grade below 1.5 in all subject except NSTP
 Magna Cum Laude - 1.26 to 1.50 (general weighted average) with no grade below 1.75 in all subjects except NSTP
 Cum Laude - 1.51 to 1.75(General weighted average) with no grade below 2.0 in all subject except NSTP
 5d. For Engineering & Architecture courses, a student shall graduate with Honors as follows:
 HONORS - NUMERICAL
 Summa Cum Laude - 1.0 to 1.25 (general weighted average) with no grade below 2.0 in all subject except NSTP
 Magna Cum Laude - 1.26 to 1.50 (general weighted average) with no grade below 2.3 in all subjects except NSTP
 Cum Laude - 1.51 to 1.75(General weighted average) with no grade below 2.5 in all subject except NSTP
 5e. A student for Non Degree program shall graduate with honors as follows:
 HONORS - NUMERICAL
 With Highest Honors - 1.0 to 1.25 (general weighted average) with no grade below 1.5 in all subject except NSTP
 With High Honors - 1.26 to 1.50 (general weighted average) with no grade below 1.8 in all subjects except NSTP
 With Honors - 1.51 to 1.75(General weighted average) with no grade below 2.0 in all subject except NSTP

 7. Secondary:
 1. The candidates for honors, at any grade or any year level, shall be drawn from the top 10% of the graduating class. They must not have a final grade lower than 80% in any subject;
 2. To determine the top 10% of the students, they shall be ranked using the 7-3 point scheme (7 points for academic performance and 3 points for co-curricular activities);
 3. The pupils/students' grades in the previous curriculum level shall not be considered in the ranking of honors for graduating pupils/students;
 4.Only the grades in the current curriculum year shall be considered in the ranking of honors for graduating students. Transferees shall be considered in the ranking provided they are enrolled not later than the second week of classes of the current school year;
 5. The final rating shall be computed to the three decimal places. In case of tie, the candidates shall both be declared in the same honor ranking (both as valedictorians or salutatorians, etc);
 6. All candidates for honors shall be of good moral character and have not been subjected to any disciplinary action within the current school year;
 7. Achievements of students in specific academic disciplines (such as Mathematics, Science and English) and in special curriculum areas (such as athletics, performing arts and campus journalism) shall be given recognition;
 8. Any member of the school selection committee must not be related within the second degree of consanguinity or affinity to any of the candidates for honors;
 9. The School Head shall be the chairman of the school selection committee composed of all subject teachers of the current year as members and shall make the final announcement of the honor students after final results have been duly recommended and approved by the Dean, Campus Director, and University President, respectively;
 10. In case of protest, it shall be filled by the candidate with his/her parents five (5) working days from the final announcement and shall be settled by the selection committee within five (5) days from the filling of the protest.
 Approved: DepEd ORDER No. 92, series of 2009

responses: To determine the top 10 of the student, they shall be ranked using the 7-3 scheme(7 points for academic performance and 3 points for co-curricular activities. They must not have a final grade lower than 80% in any subject. The students' grades in the previous curriculum level shall not be considered in the ranking of honors for graduating students. Only the grades in the current curriculum year shall be considered in the ranking of honors for graduating students. Transferees shall be considered in the ranking provided they are enrolled not later than the second week of classes of the current school year. The final rating shall be computed to the three decimal places. In case of tie, the candidates shall both be declared in the same honor ranking (both as valedictorians or salutatorians, etc.). All candidates for honors shall be of good moral character and have not been subjected to any disciplinary action within the current school year. Achievements of students in specific academic disciplines (such as Mathematics, Science and English) and in special curriculum areas (such as athletics, performing arts and campus journalism) shall be given recognition. Any member of the school selection committee must not be related within the second degree of consanguinity or affinity to any of the candidates for honors. The School Head shall be the chairman of the school selection committee composed of all subject teachers of the current year as members and shall make the final announcement of the honor students after final results have been duly recommended and approved by the Dean, Campus Director, and University President, respectively. In case of protest, it shall be filled by the candidate with his/her parents five (5) working days from the final announcement and shall be settled by the selection committee within five (5) days from the filling of the protest.

responses:
REQUIREMENTS FOR GRADUATION:
 To be eligible for graduation, the candidate must satisfy the following requirements:
 A. COLLEGE OF ADVANCED STUDIES
 1. Requirement for graduation shall either be a general grade of “1.9” or better in all format courses except thesis/dissertation. If the students fails to obtain grades which carry graduate credits as required by the particular graduate school, the rules on scholastic delinquency shall be applied.
 2. Transferees are required to establish one year residency and earn 50% of the required units for graduation.
 3. Must be fully registered student in the college/campus where the degree will be conferred.
 4. Book bound for thesis/dissertation is a requirement for graduation.
 B. UNDERGRADUATE
 1. All candidates for graduation shall make up for their deficiencies and be cleared not later than five (5) weeks before the end of their last semester.
 2. No student shall be allowed to graduate unless his name is included in the list of candidates for graduation, recommended by the Academic council and approved by the Board of Regents.
3. Must pay all required fees including graduation fees.
 4. Transferees from other colleges and universities must complete at least 50% of the number of the required units in the college where they are expected to graduate.
 5. Book bound thesis is a requirement for graduation for thesis courses.
 C. LABORATORY HIGH SCHOOL
 1. No student shall be recommended for graduation unless he has satisfied all requirements for graduation.
 2. Must pay all required fees including graduation fees.

responses:
School Policies regarding the class attendance for secondary students are as follows:
1. An excuse letter duly signed by parents will be required for three (3) consecutive absences in any subject and shall be furnished to the subject instructor and class adviser. Admission slip for absences of five (5) or more consecutive or non-consecutive meetings shall be issued by the Guidance Counselor with the approval of the Chairperson of Teacher Education Laboratory High School (TELHS).
2. Students who incurred ten (10) unexcused consecutive or non-consecutive absences will be considered dropped.

responses:
School Policies regarding the class attendance for the college students are as follows:
 1. Admission slip for absences of 5 or more consecutive or non-consecutive meetings shall be issued by the Guidance Office with the approval of the College Dean.
2. Student absences due to illness or other valid reasons may be excused upon presentation of an excuse letter from the parents/guardians with a medical certificate in case of serious illness.
3. Student who incurs five (5) unexcused consecutive or non-consecutive absences in a semester will be considered dropped.
4. Any student who is late for more than 15 minutes is admitted but considered absent.
5. Student should make up shop work/practicum/field work for unexcused absences based on the number of hours missed. Make-up for unexcused absences from shop work/practicum/field work incurred for three (3) days or more should be arranged by the teacher concerned and the College Dean and subject to the approval by the Campus Director. Activities should be in line with the subject requirement.
6. Student who cuts classes in any subject is considered absent.
7. Student who represents the campus in school-related activities whether local, provincial, regional or national level should be given the highest score obtained by the students left in class in all subjects commensurate to their absence/s. For missed periodic exam, he/she will be given special examinations two weeks after arrival.

The college's guidelines concerning the attendance of students in classes are outlined as follows:
 1. Admission slip for absences of 5 or more consecutive or non-consecutive meetings shall be issued by the Guidance Office with the approval of the College Dean.
2. Student absences due to illness or other valid reasons may be excused upon presentation of an excuse letter from the parents/guardians with a medical certificate in case of serious illness.
3. Student who incurs five (5) unexcused consecutive or non-consecutive absences in a semester will be considered dropped.
4. Any student who is late for more than 15 minutes is admitted but considered absent.
5. Student should make up shop work/practicum/field work for unexcused absences based on the number of hours missed. Make-up for unexcused absences from shop work/practicum/field work incurred for three (3) days or more should be arranged by the teacher concerned and the College Dean and subject to the approval by the Campus Director. Activities should be in line with the subject requirement.
6. Student who cuts classes in any subject is considered absent.
7. Student who represents the campus in school-related activities whether local, provincial, regional or national level should be given the highest score obtained by the students left in class in all subjects commensurate to their absence/s. For missed periodic exam, he/she will be given special examinations two weeks after arrival.

The policies regarding class attendance for college students are delineated as follows:
 1. Admission slip for absences of 5 or more consecutive or non-consecutive meetings shall be issued by the Guidance Office with the approval of the College Dean.
2. Student absences due to illness or other valid reasons may be excused upon presentation of an excuse letter from the parents/guardians with a medical certificate in case of serious illness.
3. Student who incurs five (5) unexcused consecutive or non-consecutive absences in a semester will be considered dropped.
4. Any student who is late for more than 15 minutes is admitted but considered absent.
5. Student should make up shop work/practicum/field work for unexcused absences based on the number of hours missed. Activities should be in line with the subject requirement.
6. Student who cuts classes in any subject is considered absent.
7. Student who represents the campus in school-related activities whether local, provincial, regional or national level should be given the highest score obtained by the students left in class in all subjects commensurate to their absence/s. For missed periodic exam, he/she will be given special examinations two weeks after arrival.

responses:

 5. Laboratory uniform/working clothes/PE uniform should only be worn during shop/field work/PE classes.
 6. Male students must observe the BISU prescribed haircut. Hair highlights is prohibited.

responses:
ID card is issued to students at the beginning of the school year.

1. No student will be allowed to enter the school campus and classes without an ID.
2. ID card must always be worn whenever the student is inside the campus, classes and other school related activities.
3. ID card is non-transferable. Lending one's ID card is prohibited and punishable. Violation thereof will be referred to the SAO for disciplinary action.
4. ID card of an old student shall be validated by the SAO upon enrolment.
5. Lost ID card should be reported immediately to the SAO. Affidavit of Loss must be secured before a new ID card will be issued.
6. All graduating students and those who will transfer to other schools shall surrender their school ID card to the registrar for clearance purposes.

responses: Students should make up shop work/practicum/field work for unexcused absences based on the number of hours missed. Make-up for unexcused absences from shop work/particum/ field work incurred for three (3) days or more should be arrange by the teacher concerned and the College Dean and subject to the approval by the campus Director. Activities should be in line with the subject requirements.

Students are required to compensate for unexcused absences in shop work, practicum, or fieldwork by completing additional hours corresponding to the time missed. If a student has unexcused absences for three (3) days or more, the makeup arrangements should be coordinated between the teacher and the College Dean. Approval from the campus Director is necessary for the proposed makeup plan, and the activities should align with the subject requirements.

Compensation for unexcused absences in shop work, practicum, or fieldwork mandates students to fulfill extra hours equivalent to the time missed. In the case of unexcused absences exceeding three (3) days, the coordination of makeup arrangements must involve the teacher and the College Dean. The proposed makeup plan requires approval from the campus Director, ensuring alignment with the subject requirements.

procedures of disciplinary
responses:
The college has created the STUDENT DISCIPLINE ACTION COMMITTEE (SDAC) to investigate and recommend disciplinary measures for offenses.
 DISCIPLINARY PROCEDURES ON OFFENSES:

 1. Any student who violates school policy and regulation will be referred to the Civil Security Office for investigation and to the Dean of Student Affairs for reprimand.
 2. The student will be referred to the guidance office for counseling. The Guidance Counselor should notify in writing the parents/guardians of the offenders.
 3. The Civil Security Office should submit a report to the campus director/university president for action.
 4. The campus director/university president will order the SDAC to convene for action if necessary.
 5. Student Discipline Action Committee is expected to:

 a. Review the investigation report submitted by the Civil Security Officer.
 b. Conduct another investigation for verification if necessary.
 c. Decide on the case and recommend appropriate disciplinary action to the campus director/president.
 d. Submit all facts and actions taken of the case to the Campus Director for action & copy furnished to the Dean of Student Affairs for implementation.
 e. CSO & guidance center will be given a copy for record purposes.

Once a student is enrolled in the University, one assumes responsibility to abide by her rules and regulations. The college has created the STUDENT DISCIPLINE ACTION COMMITTEE (SDAC) to investigate and recommend disciplinary measures for offenses enumerated therein.
 DISCIPLINARY PROCEDURES ON OFFENSES:

 2. The student will be referred to the guidance office for counseling. The Guidance Counselor should notify in writing the parents/guardians of the offenders.
 3. The Civil Security Office should submit a report to the campus director/university president for action.
 4. The campus director/university president will order the SDAC to convene for action if necessary.
 5. Student Discipline Action Committee is expected to:

 a. Review the investigation report submitted by the Civil Security Officer.
 b. Conduct another investigation for verification if necessary.
 c. Decide on the case and recommend appropriate disciplinary action to the campus director/president.
 d. Submit all facts and actions taken of the case to the Campus Director for action & copy furnished to the Dean of Student Affairs for implementation.
 e. CSO & guidance center will be given a copy for record purposes.

responses:
MINOR OFFENSES:

 A. Entering the campus under the influence of liquor
 1st offense: Reprimand; letter of apology duly attested by parents and/or guardians.
 2nd offense: Suspension for 1-3 school days.
 3rd offense: Suspension for 2-3 weeks

 B. Drinking alcoholic beverages within the campus jurisdiction
 1st offense: Reprimand; letter of apology duly attested by parents and/or guardians.
 2nd offense: Suspension from classes for 3-5 school days.
 3rd offense: Expulsion from the university

 C. Smoking within the school campus
 1st offense: Reprimand; letter of apology duly attested by parents and/or guardians.
 2nd offense: Suspension from classes for 3-5 school days.
3rd offense: Suspension from classes for 1-2 weeks

 D. Making unnecessary noise such as singing/ boisterous conversation/laughter/shouting causing annoyance as well as loitering in the corridor during class hours.
 1st offense: Reprimand; letter of apology duly attested by parents and/or guardians.
 2nd offense: Suspension from classes for 3 days.
3rd offense: Expulsion

 E. Engaging in any form of gambling within the campus.
 1st offense: Reprimand; letter of apology duly attested by parents and/or guardian.
 2nd offense: Suspension from classes for 3-5 days.
3rd offense: Expulsion

 F. Littering and/or dropping waste papers and plastics in the school premises.
 1st offense: Reprimand, let the student pick up pieces of paper and with letter of apology duly attested by parents and/or guardians.
 2nd offense: Suspension for 1-3 school days and let the student pick up pieces of paper.
 3rd offense: Suspension for 4-5 school days, let the student pick up pieces of paper

 G. Over speeding of pedaled or motorized vehicle and making other disturbance within the campus
 1st offense: Reprimand; letter of apology duly attested by parents and/or guardians.
 2nd offense: Suspension from classes for 2-3 school days.
 3rd offense: Suspension from classes for 4-5 school days

 H. Non-wearing of identification cards inside the campus/Lending and borrowing ID cards to other students
 1st offense: Reprimand; letter of apology duly attested by parents and/or guardians.
 2nd offense: Suspension from classes for 2 school days.
 3rd offense: Suspension from classes for 1 week 

I. Not wearing the prescribed school uniform during classes/Not wearing decent attire in transacting official business./ Sporting long hair and highlights, wearing earrings for male.
 1st offense: Reprimand; letter of apology duly attested by parents and/or guardians.
 2nd offense: No entry to the classroom or offices.
 3rd offense: Suspension for 2 days

 J. Using cellular phones inside the classroom during class hours
 1st offense: Reprimand with a letter of apology duly attested by parents and/or guardians.
 2nd offense: Confiscation of cellular phone for 2 weeks (deposited at the SAO), to be released upon presentation of a letter of apology duly attested by parents and/or guardians.
 3rd offense: Suspension from classes for 3 to 5 days.

 K. Violation of curfew hours in School Dormitory (Except when there are activities of the college where students are involved)
 1st offense: Reprimand with a letter of apology duly attested by parents and/or guardians.
 2nd offense: Expulsion from the dormitory.

responses:
Publication both print, broadcast and online of libelous statements/marks directed against the faculty, students, staff, visitors and any person in authority or their representative:

 1st Offense -Suspension from classes for 2-3 school days with letter of apology duly attested by parents and/or guardians.
 2nd Offense - Suspension from classes for 1-2 weeks
 3rd Offense -Expulsion

If you make libelous statements against faculty members, you may face a 2-3 day suspension and need to write an apology letter signed by your parents.
Printing libelous marks could result in a 2-3 day suspension and require a letter of apology signed by your parents.
Broadcasting libelous statements might lead to a 1-2 week suspension and require a letter of apology signed by your parents.
Expulsion might be the consequence if you broadcast libelous statements.

If you are found guilty of publishing libelous statements online, in print, or through broadcasts against faculty, students, staff, visitors, or authority figures, you will be suspended from classes for 2-3 days for the first offense, 1-2 weeks for the second offense, and expelled for the third offense.

responses:
Grievance Procedure on Student Complaints:

 The complaint shall be deemed instituted upon filing by any bonafide student of BISU against any member of the faculty and administration specifying the misconduct to the Grievance and Complaints Unit. It is composed of the Director of Student Affairs, Civil Security Officer, Dean of the Complainant, SSG President and Academic Adviser.
1. Notice of preliminary investigation shall then be prepared by the said unit and shall serve notices of appearance to the complainants, respondents and necessary witnesses.
2. Parents/guardians shall be notified in writing about the complaint and are invited to attend the hearing on a date set.
3. Investigation shall be conducted within five (5) working days after filing of complaint.
4. The chair of the grievance committee shall prepare a report to the campus director/SUC President, regarding the findings and possible courses of action in line with the standard security measures of the school.
5. Amicable settlement maybe reached at this stage.

Can you provide details about the library's general policies for student conduct?
How does the library regulate and enforce its rules for students?
What are the key library rules that students should be familiar with at BISU?
rules of library
responses:
Genaral Rules:

 To ensure the smooth operation of the library the following guidelines are set:
1.1 Upon entering the library all users must present their validated school ID/library card.
 1.2 The school ID/library card is presented every time a library material is borrowed/returned. These cards are non-transferable. Tampered cards will not be honored.
 1.3 The loss of a library card should be reported immediately to the Circulation Counter. The student will have to secure another library card.
 2. Defacing, mutilating and stealing of library materials are strictly prohibited.
 3. Upon leaving the library, all users must present their things for inspection.
 4. The library is mainly for research, Eating, smoking, vandalism, sleeping and group discussion are not allowed.
 5. Silence must be observed strictly at all times. Cell phones and other devices should be in a silent mode inside the library.
 6. The library should be kept clean and orderly.
 7. Newspapers and magazines should be read inside the library.
 8. Books should be left on the table after use.
 9. Library materials should be handled with care, Marking, underlining, writing, inserting bulky objects and making dog ears are prohibited.
 10. Chairs should be pushed back quietly before leaving.
 11. Damaged and lost books must be replaced.
 12. Fines will be imposed for overdue books based on the approved library user's manual.
 13. Renewal is strictly made only when the books are physically brought to the library.
 14. Non-BISU researchers or outsiders can access the library and will be charged a research fee of P50.00.
 15. Courtesy should be observed at all times when borrowing and returning books or other materials.

responses:
Inventory services involves the acquisition, maintenance and safeguarding of individual records of students. It aims to gather, organize and compile pertinent data and information of every student for its functional use. Such records include personal and educational data, lest results and other related information that are useful for the development of the client's educational, emotional spiritual and social well-being.
 A. All freshmen, returnees and transferees should have a Guidance Inventory Record which contain the result of the entrance, differential aptitude, interest, diagnostic & specials needs inventory tests.
 B. Student's inventory records should be used as reference for the development of one's educational, emotional, spiritual and social well-being.

responses:
These are the following Scholarships Bisu offers:

 1.1 HONORIFIC INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIP
 Valedictorian - 100% free tuition fee only
 Salutatorian - 50% free tuition fee only

 1.2 ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP
 The honorific scholar may continue to avail of it in the succeeding semester if he meets the required average academic requirements and is morally upright:
1. a. 1.0-1.2 with no grade below 2.0-100% free tuition.
 b. 1.21-1.3 with no grade below 2.0-80% free tuition.
 c. 1.31-1.4 with no grade below 2.0-60% free tuition.
 d. 1.41-1.5 with no grade below 2.0-40% free tuition.
 e. 1.51-1.6 with no grade below 2.0-20% free tuition.
 2. One must be a regular student.
 3. Must be up-to-date with all the academic and non- academic requirements.
 4. The academic scholarship shall only be for a period of one semester and shall continue in the succeeding semester provided the student satisfies the prescribed average grade and other requirements.
 5. A student should avail only one government scholarship.

 1.3 NON-ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS
 1.3.1 ATHLETICS
 To avail of the program:
 a. A grantee must have participated in a Regional/National Meet.
 b. Must also have passing grades in all subjects.
 c. Availment for regional achievements includes a 50% tuition and free athletic fee for gold medalists.
 25% tuition and free athletic fee for silver medalists.
  10% tuition and free athletic fee for bronze medalists.
 For national:
 100% tuition and free athletic fee-Gold medalist.
 75% tuition and free athletic fee-Silver medalist.
 50% tuition and free athletic fee-Bronze medalist.
 10% tuition and free athletic fee-non winning athletes.
 d. Must submit a certification from the Coach of the performance endorsed Coordinator of Sports and Socio-cultural Affairs, noted by the SAO and approved by the Campus Director.
 e. Must be of good moral standing.

 1.3.2 DANCE TROUPE/CHORAL GROUP
 Students must be:
 a. A bonafide college student.
. b. Must be a member of the campus dance troupe/choral group.
 c. Must be a member of the campus dance troupe/choral group.
 d. Must carry a load of at least 18 units during the current semester of the school year.
 e. Availment shall be 30% free tuition.
 f. Must have passed special/relevant screening as determined by the committee.
 g. Must have passing grades in all subjects with no grades below 2.5.
 h. Must be of good moral standing in the school and community.
 i. Must be willing to practice during and after school hours.
 j. Must comply with all academic and non-academic requirements within the period specified for completion.
 k. The contract is renewable every semester with the recommendation of the adviser.

 1.3.3 CHILDREN OF BISU PERMANENT FACULTY AND EMPLOYEES
 Scholarship in the Undergraduate program.
 B. Discount of 50 % per child on tuition fees.
 C. Maximum of four (4) children only.

 1.3.4 MS. BISU/SCUAA
 a. Reigning Ms. BISU/SCUAA for the School Year.
 b. Full free tuition and other fees during the School Year to be shouldered by the winning campus.

responses:
Applicants must be:
 Any bonafide student of BISU can avail of the student assistantship program during his/her free periods and off-school hours with a maximum rate per hour as prescribed by the BOR not more than 4 hours a day and 8 hours on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays but not to exceed 100 hours per month within the semester.
 1. The applicant must secure the application form from the Student Affairs Office and ask recommendation from the Project In-charge/office head. The SAO will endorse the application to the Campus Director for approval.
 2. The official time for duty will be during their free periods and off-hours.
 3. Student assistant who renders services in the evening should be up to 9:00 pm. should there be a need for extra service he may be allowed to stay/sleep in school.
 4. Student assistant should be assigned in line with his course specialization as the case maybe.
 5. Student Assistant shall be paid monthly.

responses:
BISU allows:
 1. Only bonafide students of BISU may organize any Campus Student Organization.
 2. All Campus Student Organizations (CSO) must be duly screened, registered, recognized and accredited by the Dean of Student Affairs.
 3. Campus organizations must comply with all the Student Affairs Office (SAO) requirements for registration, recognition and accreditation as follows:
 1. Application form.
 2. Police Clearance of the organizer.
 3. Proposed Constitution and By-laws.
 4. List of Charter Members (at least 30).
 5. List of officers with recent ID picture.
 6. Two (2) nominees from regular staff members of BISU who shall be appointed as organization advisers by the Campus Director/University President upon recommendation of the Department Dean and Dean SAO.
 7. Proposed Work Plan of Annual Activities and Budget.
 8. Registration fee of P50.00.
 4. A newly formed organization shall be recognized on probation basis for at least one school year.
 5. Full recognition of an organization shall be based on the evaluation conducted by the Committee on Student Organization headed by the Dean of SAO, SSG Adviser and Guidance Counselor.
 6. Existing organizations who wish to renew their recognition must submit the following documents for renewal:
 Requirements for Renewal:
 1. Application for renewal of recognition.
 2. Accomplishment Report with pictorials.
 3.Updated list of members with respective signature.
 4. Work plan for the school year.
 5. Annual evaluation result must have at least 250 points earned (See list of activities & corresponding points in Student Affairs Manual).
 6. Activities and programs sponsored, spearheaded and organized by the CSO for academic enrichment, cultural purposes, fund raising campaigns and educational field’s trips, within and outside of the campus must secure activity permits from the SAO and Department Deans. It shall be approved by the Campus Director/President upon the recommendation by College Dean and Student Affairs.
 7. Approved activity of CSO must be submitted to the SAO at least two weeks before the activity.
 8. CSO posters, announcements and streamers must be approved by the SAO for posting. These must be posted only at designated places and bulletin boards.
 9. Posters, announcements and streamers should be removed after serving their purposes.
 10. An elected appointed CSO president can no longer be a president of another organization.

responses:
To apply this program:
 1. The TESDA (Technical Education & Skills Development Authority) conducts a yearly Trade Skill Test to BISU graduating students in the designed testing center of skills accreditation.
 2. The Trade Skills Test comes in two phases: Knowledge and Skills. For the skills test, the examinee will provide his own materials.
 3. The applicant fills up the appropriate application form and pays the corresponding trade testing fee to TESDA.
 4. An examinee must pass both the knowledge and skills tests before he is issued a Trade Skills Certificate by TESDA
